title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" is the short title of this legislation. Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job opportunities, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation. There is a consensus on the importance of raising academic standards and modeling them after advanced placement programs, which are endorsed by education leaders and half of all States. Advanced placement courses offer 30 college-level courses, are taken by almost 60% of secondary schools, and benefit over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges. The advanced placement programs benefit over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges and universities. 24 States are funding programs to increase participation in advanced placement programs, including funding for teacher professional development, requiring schools to offer advanced placement courses, paying fees for tests, and granting academic credit for passing scores. These programs have raised academic standards for students. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams by highlighting the benefits of such programs, including improved skills, higher SAT scores, and better academic performance in school and college. State programs have shown success in increasing enrollment, achievement, and minority participation in advanced placement programs. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by improving skills, raising academic standards, expanding program availability, and diversifying student participation. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by providing greater access for low-income and disadvantaged students, increasing participation rates to 25% of the student population, and expanding access for juniors in schools without advanced placement programs. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for a 3-year period to carry out authorized activities, with payments made annually. Eligible entities include State and local educational agencies. Priority will be given to entities demonstrating a need for advanced placement programs and involvement of business and community organizations. The subsection (d) outlines criteria for eligible entities to receive grants for advanced placement programs, including the involvement of business and community organizations, matching funds from State or local sources, a focus on English, mathematics, and science, and targeting schools with a high concentration of low-income students. An eligible entity may use grant funds to expand access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals through various activities such as teacher training, curriculum development, and providing books and supplies. Each entity must submit an application to the Secretary for consideration. Each eligible entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. Recipients of the grant must report annually on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, tests taken, scores, and demographic details. The Secretary compiles this data and reports to Congress. The Secretary compiles data from eligible entities on students' advanced placement courses, tests, scores, and demographic details. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies for on-line advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for curriculum purchase, teacher training, or course materials. Applications for grants are required from each agency. Grant funds can be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit applications for grants. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. The text discusses the dissemination of Advanced Placement information by institutions of higher education and the standardization of how this information is distributed. It also mentions amendments to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act regarding Javits gifted and talented students. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include programs for gifted and talented students that incorporate advanced placement courses. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is also amended to prioritize upward bound projects focusing on increasing student participation in advanced placement courses. Additionally, the Eisenhower professional development program is updated to include federal activities. The Eisenhower professional development program is amended to prioritize training in advanced placement instruction for federal activities. State and local activities are also updated to include professional development activities in advanced placement instruction. The Technology section of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to encourage the delivery of advanced placement instruction to underserved communities. Additionally, education technology grants are updated to include support for advanced placement instruction. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to support advanced placement instruction in underserved communities through education technology grants. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to support advanced placement instruction in underserved communities through education technology grants. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines terms like "advanced placement incentive program" as providing activities for low-income individuals, "advanced placement test" as administered by the College Board, "high concentration of low-income students" as serving 40% or more students from low-income families, and "low-income individual" as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "low-income individual" in the Act refers to a person who meets the criteria outlined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, is academically prepared for advanced placement tests, and is determined by a school teacher or coordinator. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965, and terms like "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "State" refers to various entities including the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and other territories. The term "Secretary" specifically means the Secretary of Education.
